asked the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice:

item.para: Did he make a statement which justified the entry of Trans-Australia Airlines to the Perth-Darwin route, by saying that one reason was that Ansett Airlines of Australia, through MacRobertson Miller Airline services, charged first class fares between intermediate stops.
If so, and if TAA introduces economy fares between intermediate stops, will he ensure that the same scale of fares is charged by TAA and Ansett on their internal flights in the Northern Territory.

If the introduction of economy fares on these fights results in unprofitable services, will the Government consider supporting their operation so that outback intermediate airports do not suffer from reduced services.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: I have stated that, following the entry of Trans-Australia Airlines on the Perth-Darwin route, the airline will introduce economy class fares on this service, a facility which has not previously, been made available by MacRobertson Miller Airline services.

Economy class fares are introduced by the airlines when they consider that this step will generate sufficient additional traffic and revenue to offset revenue lost through the diversion of first class traffic to economy class travel. This principle applies throughout Australia, including the Northern Territory.

The Government does not contemplate encouraging the adoption of fares which will result in additional uneconomic air services requiring governmental financial support at the expense of the general taxpayer.

answer.para: Executions in Yugoslavia (Question No. 517)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice:

item.para: What steps has the Government taken to inquire into the arrest, trial, appeal and execution of Mirko Vlasnovic in Yugoslavia by Yugoslavian authorities.
Will he table full details in the House.
What charges were preferred against Vlasnovic and who undertook his defence.
Is he able to say why the Australian Government was not advised that Vlasnovic and his colleagues survived the Bosnian incursion and of his arrest.
Who were the survivors of the incursion and what is the present position with respect to each of them.
What other Australians are currently held by the Yugoslavian Government, and what charges have been preferred against each of them.
What opportunity has been given each of these arrested Australian nationals to discuss the circumstances of his case with the resident Australian Embassy officials.
What assistance has been offered by Australia for their defence.
Will he obtain and table full details of all proceedings initiated against them.

Was any of the evidence advanced against any arrested Australian citizen in Yugoslavia obtained through actions initiated in Australia by the Australian Attorney-General; if so, what was that evidence.

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

item.para: As soon as the Yugoslav authorities announced that Mirko Vlasnovic had been executed, a formal request was made by the Australian Ambassador in Belgrade for full details of the arrest, trial and conviction of all of the Australian involved. The Yugoslav authorities have indicated an 'intention to provide the information sought but it has not as yet been received.
A decision on whether or not to table the details will be made when they have been received and examined.
Until we receive details of the charges and the court proceedings from the Yugoslav authorities, I am unable to say.

As well as being Australian citizens, Vlasnovic and his colleagues were also nationals of Yugoslavia. The Yugoslav authorities consequently contend that, in accordance with the principle of 'master nationality', there was no obligation for them to advise the Australian Government
Until we receive details from the Yugoslav authorities, I am unable to say.

and (7) There are reports that there are a number of Australians at present being detained in Yugoslavia for a variety of reasons. The Australian Embassy has made official representations to the Yugoslav authorities in respect of each case which has come to its notice, in an effort to verify the information and to obtain details of the charges involved. Again, all of these cases involve the problem of 'dual nationality' and the Yugoslav authorities have contended that the Australian representatives cannot claim a right to the information or access to the persons concerned.

Negotiations are continuing with the Yugoslav authorities on the question of consular access in cases involving dual nationality. I am hopeful that the improved relations between the 2 Governments will ultimately lead to the development of a satisfactory working arrangement so that some assistance can be given to such persons.
Until full details of the charges and proceedings are obtained, it would be premature to comment on the appropriateness of them being made public in the manner suggested.
Similarly, I am not in a position to make any statement about the evidence used until details of the court proceedings are made available by the Yugoslav authorities.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: Based on population projections by the Commonwealth Statistician it is estimated that in Australia at April 1973 there were 454,800 men aged 65 years and over and 888,700 women aged 60 years and over who were qualified by residence for an age pension.
At 27 March 1973, the percentage of existing pensioners who were eligible for one or more of the fringe benefits provided by the Australian Government was as follows:

Adequate data is not available from which to reliably estimate the additional cost of making fringe benefits and concessions available to all eligible people, if the means tests on both pensions and fringe benefits were abolished.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice:

item.para: Is it a fact that salaries of diplomatic staff in Phnom Penh have been reduced.
If so, why have these persons been selected for this discriminating action.
Will he take steps to have these salaries raised to the level of other diplomatic staff.
Will he have a check made on the working conditions of the diplomatic staff in Phnom Penh which are reported as being badly neglected.

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows: (1), (2) and (3). The salaries of diplomatic staff serving in Phnom Penh have not been reduced. They are identical to the salaries paid to Australian diplomatic staff of the same rank stationed elsewhere. However, subsequent to a Public Service Board inspection last year of localliving costs and following several currency variations the local allowances which supplement the salaries of officers in Phnom Penh have been reduced (in some cases to nil).

item.para: Working and living conditions in Phnom Penh are being improved. A new building has been leased to replace the present over-crowded Chancery and is currently being remodelled. A major refurnishing scheme is in progress to bring staff residences to a more acceptable standard. The Public Service Board has also approved or has currently under consideration further proposals aimed at improving living conditions through additional recreational facilities and special allowances to take account of particularly difficult local circumstances.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice:

quote.para: Has the Australian Government taken any action to protest against (a) the judicial murder of a family of 5 Iraqi Jews in Baghdad and the previous public hanging of Jews in that city; (b) the detention and murder of Pakistani prisoners-of-war in Indian POW camps; and (c) the judicial murder of Asian and Ugandan citizens in Uganda.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: On 3 February 1969 the then Australian Government protested to the President of the Security Council and to the Secretary-General of the United Natrons at the public execution of 9 Jews in Baghdad earlier that year. In respect of reports that further executions of Jews have recently taken place in Iraq, Australian diplomatic missions in the area have been asked to try to ascertain the facts. Australia does not, however, have a resident diplomat mission in Baghdad.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The Australian Government maintains regular contact with the Governments of India, Pakistan and Bangladesh in relation to their attempts to find a solution to the outstanding problems of the South Asian sub-continent. In maintaining these contacts the Government has been aware of the determination of India and Pakistan, expressed in the Simla Agreement of July 1972, to resolve these problems bilaterally, without outside interference. The return of the Pakistani prisoners of war detained in India is one of a number of inter-related problems, Including the recognition of Bangladesh by Pakistan, the prospect of war crimes trials in Bangladesh, the repatria tion of Bengalis detained in Pakistan and of those non-Bengalis in Bangladesh who have opted for repatriation to Pakistan, and the division of assets and liabilities between Pakistan and Bangladesh. The Government welcomes the Joint Declaration made by India and Bangladesh on 17 April as an attempt to move out of the existing stalemate. While recognising the complexity of the issues involved, the Government hopes that further progress towards an early solution acceptable to all parties can be made. The Governments of India, Pakistan and Bangladesh are aware of our views on these matters.

item.label: (c)
item.para: As the Special Minister of State stated in the Senate on 23 March, the Government deplores recent events in Uganda.
